Literature Review: The intersection of competition policy and environmental sustainability represents a burgeoning field of study, challenging traditional paradigms of antitrust law and industrial organization. Historically, competition law has prioritized consumer welfare, often measured through price effects and market efficiency, without explicit consideration of environmental impacts. However, as societal priorities shift towards sustainability, there is an increasing call for competition policy to evolve and incorporate environmental considerations into its framework (Amato, 1997). This evolution necessitates a reevaluation of how competition authorities assess agreements between firms, particularly those aimed at developing sustainable technologies and products. Recent legal reforms in various jurisdictions have begun to address this gap, allowing for the consideration of sustainability benefits in the assessment of cooperative agreements among competitors (OECD, 2020). This shift opens new avenues for research, particularly in the integration of industrial organization theory with environmental and resource economics. One of the key challenges in this integration is the development of measurement techniques that can accurately quantify the environmental benefits of such agreements, balancing them against potential anti-competitive effects (Baker & Salop, 2015). The literature suggests that sustainability agreements can lead to significant environmental benefits, such as reduced carbon emissions and enhanced resource efficiency, but these must be carefully weighed against the risk of reduced competition and innovation (Geradin & Petit, 2017). Furthermore, the role of firm green preferences in shaping competitive dynamics has emerged as a critical area of study. Firms increasingly recognize the value of sustainability not only as a regulatory compliance issue but also as a competitive advantage, influencing their strategic decisions and market behavior (Porter & van der Linde, 1995). This has led to a growing interest in understanding how competition policy can encourage firms to internalize environmental externalities, promoting a more sustainable economy. The literature also highlights the potential for competition policy to support the transition to a circular economy, where the focus shifts from linear production models to more sustainable, closed-loop systems (Stahel, 2016). However, achieving this requires a nuanced understanding of the trade-offs involved, as well as the development of policy tools that can effectively balance competition and sustainability objectives. In conclusion, the integration of environmental considerations into competition policy represents a complex but necessary evolution, with significant implications for both theory and practice. As this field continues to develop, it will be crucial for researchers and policymakers to collaborate in exploring innovative approaches that can reconcile the goals of competition and sustainability, ensuring a more resilient and environmentally friendly economic system.
